ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to think critically about censorship and its implications in art, government, and film to name a few examples. I learned how to reflect on examples of injustice and censorship in society.
I developed critical thinking skills that allowed me to do intensive research on everyday problems.

This course taught me foundational skills to college writing. Professor Robinson allowed us to explore a variety of style reminding us of basic and key techniques in clear text. I learned how to synthesis information, how develop a strong claim, and how to utilize the bass research platforms at Yale.
I learned a lot more about censorship in the world today and in a historical context. I also learned a lot about constructing a good claim.
I learned the various different methods of writing papers, ranging from Op-eds, analysis, and research papers.
Research, writing, and speaking in a class skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think it would be helpful for this course to have more structure, though I think it's also nice how the schedule leaves room for open conversation. I think it would have been better for the readings to have been more concise.
It sometimes felt a little lecture-y instead of a seminar.

Weaknesses: Not as much one-on-one interactions with teacher unless requested by student
Strengths: Productive class discussions

This class had very interesting readings and discussions. The topic of "Censorship" is applicable to pretty much all aspects of life and in our time is very relevant. I loved our seminar style class and the work load was very reasonable. I would have love to spend more time with Yale librarians as our class visit provided very great insight.

Strengths: the Professor brought current events into the conversation, which we looked at through the lens of the course topic of censorship.
Weaknesses/improvements: despite being a seminar, this class was mostly lecture. I wish I had been able to have more discussions directly with my classmates.
The strengths of this course are that it is not tailored to a specific student audience, meaning anyone can excel in the course.

Strengths: great class for first years because it was very manageable.
Weaknesses: none

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to another student that is curious about the subject.
Yes I would recommend! Relatively interesting topic and light workload

Yes. Prof. Robinson is amazing. The topic is very interesting, and he always manages to make class interesting. The workload is also very do-able, and Prof. Robinson is always very understanding of any situation.
Yes I definitely would especially if they are interested in law school and would want to grapple with intensive concepts revolving freedom of speech.

I would recommend this course to a student. The central topic of "Censorship in the arts" is very engaging, the work load is very reasonable, and it provide me with a great foundation to college writing.
I don't think I'd recommend this course to another student. I wish I had been more intellectually challenged.
I would recommend this course to a freshman/sophomore seeking to expose themselves to the expectations of Yale writing.
Yes, because the work load was not too much and I learned a lot.
